title: Should Babies Get a Shot to Stay Healthy?
summary: A group of doctors and experts is having a meeting to talk about a vaccine for babies. The vaccine helps protect against a sickness called hepatitis B, which can hurt the liver. Right now, doctors say all babies should get this shot on their first day of life. But some people, including a committee led by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., might want to change this rule. Other doctors, like those from the American Academy of Pediatrics, say the vaccine is important because it saves lives by preventing cancer and other liver problems. The meeting will happen live, so people can watch and learn more about why this decision is being made. It's a big discussion about keeping babies safe and healthy.

background_read: Hepatitis B is a sickness that can make the liver very sick. Babies can get it from their moms when they are born. The vaccine is a shot that helps stop this sickness. Doctors have been giving it to babies for many years to keep them healthy. Some people are now talking about whether this is still the best idea. This meeting will help decide what to do next.
Article_Structure: WHO: A federal vaccine advisory committee and doctors like Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Dr. Sean O'Leary
WHAT: A debate about whether newborns should get the hepatitis B vaccine
WHERE: In the United States, with a live meeting online
WHY: To discuss if the current rule for vaccinating babies should be changed to protect their health
